title: The trade war gets real for Aussie investors
text:
Hopes had been rising that this latest round of talks could produce some sort of truce, perhaps the US rolling back some tariffs in exchange for China stepping up its purchases of US agricultural products.

But these hopes were dampened last week after Trump publicly urged China to investigate former US vice-president Joseph Biden and his family, thereby ensuring that any agreement would be scrutinised.

The Trump administration further fuelled tensions between the two countries this week when it announced that an additional 28 Chinese entities would be blacklisted from buying US-made technology.

Huge global cost

As the trade war has dragged on – at a cost to the global economy of about $US700 billion ($1.04 trillion) by 2020 – Beijing's stance has changed. In the first year, the official line was that the dispute would not damage the Chinese economy and that the main victims would be American companies.

As China's economic slowdown has become more entrenched, the new slogan is that there are no winners in trade and technology wars.

Last month, its top diplomat, Wang Yi, warned that tariffs and technology disputes could plunge the world into recession.

"Tariffs and provocation of trade disputes, which upset global industrial and supply chains, serve to undermine the multilateral trade regime and global economic trade order", he said in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

It also appears that losing access to critical technology is of greater concern to Beijing than rising tariffs.

This month, the nationalist Chinese tabloid Global Times – which is published by the Chinese Communist Party's mouthpiece, the People's Daily – said there was "nothing to be gained from erecting digital versions of the Berlin Wall".

It said a "win-win cooperation should be the aim of all major technology-producing nations".

Ambitious growth targets.

At the top level of the Chinese hierarchy, there is a growing recognition of the challenge of meeting ambitious growth targets.

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang admitted last month that it was "very difficult" for China's economy to grow at a rate of 6 per cent or more, because of slowing global growth and rising protectionism.

Beijing had set a target for the world's second-largest economy to grow by between 6 per cent and 6.5 per cent this year. According to Chinese officials, it grew 6.2 per cent between April and June compared with a year earlier, its slowest pace in nearly three decades.

Economists expect Chinese growth to slip below 6 per cent in the coming months as the escalating trade war saps confidence, causing businesses to scale back their investment plans.

This leaves Beijing with a difficult trade-off. If Chinese policymakers encourage businesses and local governments to borrow and invest more to boost growth, they risk injecting yet more instability into the country's financial system.
description: Aussie investors had hoped they could avoid becoming collateral damage in the US-China trade war. But their confidence has been shaken as Beijing struggles to fire up the Chinese economy, writes Karen Maley.
